item.title: Creating Contact Groups
item.description:
What are Contact Groups link

Contact Groups are a powerful classification tool that enables customer support teams to efficiently manage and organize customer information. This feature allows visual and logical tagging of “Contacts” and “Companies” associated with tickets. Through this grouping, agents can immediately understand customer characteristics and priority levels.

How to Create Contact Groups link

Navigating to Settings link

From the agent screen left menu, select “Settings” > “Automation” > “Contact Groups”. On this screen, you can create new groups and manage existing groups.

item.title: Creating Tags
item.description:
What are Tags link

“Tags” are an important feature in SmartWeb’s ticket management that enables efficient categorization and analysis. They can be manually applied to tickets by agents or automatically applied based on system rules. Using tags makes it easy to organize and optimize customer support processes.

How to Create Tags link

Creating tags can be easily done from the SmartWeb management screen. Agents can quickly identify ticket characteristics and status using visually clear color coding and understandable names.

item.title: How to Automatically Assign Tickets to Agents Who Reply
item.description:
Overview of Automatic Ticket Assignment Rules link

This guide explains how to set up a rule that automatically assigns tickets to agents when they respond to those tickets.

Importance of Automatic Ticket Assignment Rules link

Challenges with Manual Assignment link

When responding to new tickets, if agents forget to manually perform the “Other” > “Assign to me” operation within the ticket, the ticket will be saved without being assigned to any specific agent.

item.title: How to Configure SLA Settings
item.description:
About SLA link

SLA (Service Level Agreement) is a quality standard for your company’s customer support. By defining time limits for responding to tickets, you can manage support quality.

SLA settings in LiveAgent have “Levels (priority)” and “Rules (conditions)”. By combining these two elements, LiveAgent automatically adjusts ticket prioritization according to inquiry situations such as “standard time”, “emergency”, and “incident occurrence”.

How to Configure SLA link

Select Settings > Automation > SLA from the menu.

item.title: How to Set Up Rules
item.description:
What are Rules link

You can create “rules” to automatically process tickets in LiveAgent based on your specific business processes. If you can think of rules for your business operations, you can create either “time-based” or “regular rules”.

“Rules” allow you to complete tickets under certain conditions, add tags (categorize content), increase ticket priority by customer (improves display order), or automatically process unnecessary inquiries. By clarifying business processes, rules can be set up and automation can be advanced.

item.title: How to Set Up Time Rules
item.description:
What are Time Rules link

You can create “Time Rules” based on your unique business processes. If you can think of rules within your business operations, you can create either “Time-based” or “Regular Rules”.

For example, through time rule settings, it becomes possible to “automatically complete tickets” if there is no action from customers 24 hours after responding to a ticket, “automatically send emails after 3 days”, or “tag tickets that remain unresolved after a week”.

item.title: Is there a way to register multiple condition keywords in rule settings?
item.description:
Method for Registering Multiple Keywords link

Keyword Configuration Using Regular Expressions link

When creating rule application conditions, regular expression functionality is convenient for registering multiple keywords in a single configuration item. Regular expressions are a powerful tool that allows advanced control over string pattern matching, enabling flexible condition specification in SmartWeb rule settings.

Specifically, by separating keywords with “|” (pipe), you can search for multiple keywords simultaneously. For example, by setting “apple|banana|orange”, you can extract content that matches any of these three keywords.

item.title: Rule Settings (Rules)
item.description:
Overview of Rule Settings link

A feature that allows you to create conditional rules to automate ticket processing. Automatically executes actions on tickets that match specific conditions.

Specific Examples of Rule Settings link

For example, you can implement automation such as “Always set high priority for inquiries from VIP customers” or “Send automatic reply emails for inquiries received outside business hours.”

Main Benefits of Rule Settings link

Improved Operational Efficiency link

  • Achieve automation through conditional rules
  • Reduce manual work for agents

Enhanced Customer Support Quality link

  • Automatically execute priority settings and auto-replies
  • Support SLA compliance
  • Contribute to standardized customer experience

item.title: Search & Replace
item.description:
Overview of Search & Replace link

A function that searches the content of received tickets and automatically replaces specified strings with other strings. Useful for standardizing common terminology and correcting typos.

Use Cases link

For example, you can automatically correct “Product A” to “Product Name: A Series” to standardize brand terminology and expressions. This reduces agent workload and maintains consistent communication.

Key Features and Benefits link

Key Points:

  • Search and replace message content
  • Standardize terminology and correct typos
  • Manage expressions that protect brand image
  • Automate tasks for improved efficiency
  • Provide consistent customer support

item.title: Service-level Agreement (SLA)
item.description:
What is a Service Level Agreement (SLA) link

Basic Concept of SLA link

A feature that sets target response times and resolution times for customer support and manages compliance status. It can send alerts to prevent SLA violations.

Specific Configuration Examples link

For example, you can set standards such as “initial response within 1 hour” and “resolution within 24 hours,” and create a system that automatically issues warnings for unhandled tickets. This allows you to achieve both customer satisfaction and contract compliance.

item.title: SLA Compliance Report
item.description:
Overview of SLA Compliance Report link

What is an SLA Compliance Report link

The SLA Compliance Report is a feature that measures and analyzes whether Service Level Agreements (SLA) are being adhered to. It allows you to clearly understand on-time response rates and violation counts.

Main Functions of SLA Reports link

For example, if you guarantee an initial response within 24 hours, the system can automatically calculate the achievement rate and list cases that didn’t meet the requirement. This enables early detection of areas that need improvement.

item.title: SLA Log Report
item.description:
Overview of SLA Log Report link

The SLA Log Report is a feature that records and tracks all history related to SLAs. You can view in detail when, on which tickets, and how SLAs were complied with or violated.

Main Purpose of SLA Log Report link

SLA History Management link

Administrators can use this report to identify trends and causes of SLA violations. For example, it’s possible to discover issues concentrated in specific time periods or departments.

item.title: Time rules
item.description:
What are Time Rules link

Time rules are a feature that allows you to set up rules that operate automatically at regular intervals. They execute processes periodically on tickets that meet specified conditions.

Main Features and Use Cases link

For example, you can automate tasks like “Check unhandled tickets every hour and send alerts.” This helps prevent oversights and missed tickets.

Main Benefits link

Key Points:

  • Set up automatic rules that execute periodically
  • Send automatic alerts for unhandled tickets
  • Prevent oversights and ensure response quality
  • Reduce agent workload
  • Support SLA compliance

item.title: Time tracking
item.description:
Time tracking Overview link

A feature that allows recording response time for each ticket. Enables accurate tracking of how much time agents spend on tasks.

Purpose and Benefits of Time Tracking link

By collecting data such as “average 30 minutes for technical support” or “average 10 minutes for billing-related inquiries,” you can improve operations and resource allocation.

Key Features link

Key Points:

  • Ability to record response time for each ticket
  • Can be used for workload management and operational improvement
  • Helps optimize resource allocation
  • Visualizes agent productivity
  • Improves accuracy of cost calculations and estimates

item.title: To Improve LiveAgent Operational Efficiency
item.description:
Overview of LiveAgent Customer Support Features link

LiveAgent provides not only customer support itself, but also numerous extended features that support customer service operations.

Service Level Agreement (SLA) Management link

Basic Concept of SLA link

SLA (Service Level Agreement) is a guarantee of service quality that is clearly shown to customers. In LiveAgent, it is defined as the time limit for responding to customer inquiries (tickets).

SLA Configuration and Operation link

To comply with this “time limit” in LiveAgent, you set up two components: “SLA levels” that define different time limits for different scenarios, and “SLA rules” that define the conditions for level assignment. For example, by establishing a rule such as “if the customer group is VIP,” “email responses must be within 30 minutes during business hours,” you can change the flow of operations.

item.title: Using and Creating Email Canned Responses
item.description:
What are Email Canned Responses link

“Email Canned Responses” are response templates that can be called when composing messages on LiveAgent, such as replying to emails or creating internal tickets. Unlike the similar “Frequently Used Phrases” feature, “Email Canned Responses” differ in that they allow editing with HTML tags and file attachments.

“Email Canned Responses” are suitable for customer support that involves technical content or sending files such as materials.

item.title: Using and Creating Predefined Answers
item.description:
What are Predefined Answers link

Predefined Answers are templates that can be called upon when composing messages in LiveAgent, such as email replies, live chat, and internal tickets. While there is a similar feature called “Email Templates,” Predefined Answers differ in that they offer capabilities like HTML tag editing and file attachments.

Predefined Answers are suitable for standardizing agent language for simple greetings and questions.

How to Use Predefined Answers link

How to Call Predefined Answers link

To use Predefined Answers, click the “speech bubble” icon in the bottom right of the message reply form on the agent screen.
